title: ENG09_pt 1: 2.4 Identity: Who am I? | SVHS

mainContent.text:
2.4 Identity: Who am I?

        Completion requirements
        



The Age-Old Question
The greatest of all epic heroes, young Odysseus, had it all: good looks, courage, cunning, and a great beard.  After all, he was the greatest living mortal who had helped the Greeks win the 10-year Trojan War.  But, the young Odysseus didn't really know himself, such was his hubris (excessive pride).  It took him 20 years lost at sea, suffering, his crew all dying in order for the now old Odysseus to realize his identity was that of a mortal (a human) and not an immortal (or a god).  
Archetypal characters, like the young Odysseus, who are full of pride, are called "alazons."  These characters think they are better than they really are.  They are deceivers, imposters who serve themselves,
    instead of others.
Alazons in literature include: Satan, Voldemort, Darth Vader, the Joker, Scar, and the Wicked Stepmother (Cinderella).  These villains abuse power; they are vengeful and spiteful; they are part of the "me" culture.
Archetypal characters, like the old Odysseus, who are humble are called "eirons."  These are characters who are better than they think they are.  They are self-deprecating, who serve others, not themselves.
Eirons in literature include: Christ, Harry Potter, Luke Skywalker, Batman, Simba, and Cinderella.  Eirons know they have growth potential; they need allies for support; they are charitable and loving; they are part of the "we" culture.
Let's learn more about how we construct ourselves and our identities, how we tell our own stories.
Watch the following videos to learn more:





Reading:
The Themes of Identity and Prejudice in American Born Chinese
